Award.AwardTitle: The Potential Contribution of Indigenous Knowledge to Teaching and Learning Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration: This is an interdisciplinary research project that focuses on collaborative, cross-cultural research into Indigenous knowledge systems via mathematics. The research team is made up of indigenous and non-indigenous researchers who will study the infusion of mathematics in Indigenous Knowledge systems (IKS) and studies how these mathematical knowledge systems are embedded and encoded into everyday activities. The central hypothesis of this project is that "...embedded in traditional indigenous knowledge systems--within their worldview, their way of knowing, and their way of doing...are elegant solutions that are mathematically rich." (from star navigation, to patterns for clothing to building a kayak...) The project will take place in three different arctic cultural, linguistic, and geographical regions: Yup'ik (Alaska), Sami (Norway and Sweden) and Koryak (Kamchatka) with a comparative site in Yap (a Federated State in Micronesia) as a control group. The project aims to do more than just document the ethnomathematics; the project will contextualize this kind of knowledge in broader cultural epistemologies and will also examine the indigenous pedagogies by which people learn the activities and the embedded mathematics. In addition to exploring mathematic conceptualizations the project will also record the language of mathematics, which is endangered among all of these groups and an aspect of language that is rarely captured by linguists working with endangered languages. Perhaps most importantly, it has the potential to add to human knowledge about how everyday problems and tasks are solved without using Western instrumentation; if similar mathematically-oriented processes are used across project sites this may well suggest will universal concepts rather than culturally particularlistic ones. Hence, this project has the potential to establish an alternative learning trajectory based on IKS for the teaching of mathematics in indigenous and non indigenous contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This interdisciplinary, cross-cultural and international research project developed from a thirty-year-long collaboration between the Principal Investigator and a deeply committed group of Yupiaq elders, teachers, and university scholars. During our long-term collaboration to elicit Indigenous Knowledge (IK) and integrate it into school curricula, we slowly recognized the centrality of mathematical concepts. We found that they were embedded in the way that IK holders thought about and performed a wide variety of everyday activities. Specifically, these ways of thinking and doing connected symmetry and measurement to precision and beauty in the making of objects that range from hats to houses. These concepts and ways of thinking and doing are founded on and arise from the human body’s right/left axis of symmetry. From early archaeological records we can see that across the globe humans have employed symmetrical perspectives in making tools, beautiful artwork, buildings, even villages. Modern mathematics and physics have relied on symmetry, for new advances in quantum physics. Symmetry and its association with measuring are powerful concepts that offer scholars and practitioners a way to perceive, think, plan, and act. Yet, school mathematics treat symmetry and measuring as isolated topics in the overall mathematics curriculum. The project sought to understand the mathematical connections across everyday activities and if possible apply them to teaching school mathematics.

The project took place in diverse Indigenous contexts that still perform traditional activities. Three different Arctic cultural, linguistic, and geographical regions were included—Yup’ik in Alaska, Sami in Norway and Sweden, and Koryak in Kamchatka. A fourth site in Micronesia with the island nation of Yap provided a contrasting geographical, environmental, cultural, and linguistic context.

 Each group used symmetry and measuring in their everyday activities. Surprisingly, the group outwardly most different from the Yupiaq Eskimo has the greatest degree of similarity. We spent a considerable amount of time with IK holders from the Federated States of Micronesia, particularly on the island nation of Yap. Evidence suggests that their complex system of star navigating at sea is based on a symmetrically oriented sky map, measuring and locating islands in relation to the night sky procession. Four key directions established their orientation system. This was strikingly similar to what one Yupiaq elder called the right-angled, symmetrical axes, symbolized by “+”, the beginning of everything. In the Yup’ik conception, the intersection of two perpendicular lines creating a center point start in the body and are the orienting center point from which actions occur; it is the place from which to measure.  Measuring was also understood as a comparison of two quantities. The comparison of quantities results in a ratio, For example, assume that Length A is exactly twice Length B: comparing Length A / Length B is a ratio which equals  2/1.

 The research group identified symmetry, measuring, center point and centerline, physical proofing, and halving as concepts that appear across activities, genders, and cultural groups. We more clearly realized that these dynamic concepts have implications for schooling. Elders began to show how they make a variety of geometrical shapes (squares, rectangles, parallelograms, hexagons, circles, and others). The elders mostly constructed these shapes by using symmetry, measuring, center point, and the required properties to make the desired shape. This has direct implications for teaching geometry—from constructing geometrical shapes to understanding their properties to learning how to verify congruence and equality. Measuring from a center point resembles the way that mathematicians think about positive and negative numbers on a number line. In other words, numbers are equally spaced along a line, and the same value for positive and negative numbers display symmetry across the center point, which is zero. Beyond counting numbers and positive and negative integers, rational (fractions), and irrationals numbers are also constructed from the same fundamental symmetric structure and processes such as measuring and halving. Similarly, the same way of perceiving, thinking, and acting using the concept of number and balance provides a pathway to support early algebraic reasoning. Is this side (of the equation or the length of one side of a square) equal to the other side? Our group was able to develop ways of teaching place value starting with base 2 using the concepts of halving, measuring, and symmetry, as well as demonstrate how these same concepts can be used as a way to teach trigonometry. These few examples begin to provide a sense of the cohesiveness of symmetry and measuring across mathematics strands.

We believe this project has shown that learning from IK and adapting the fundamental principles that IK holders use in thinking, planning, creating tools, and conducting everyday activities is applicable to classroom teaching. We think these principles have the potential to provide another way of teaching the foundations of mathematical thinking in an accessible and cohesive way.
